sen.j: 高階 泰経（たかしな の やすつね、大治5年（1130年） - 建仁元年11月23日 (旧暦)（1201年12月20日））は平安時代末期から鎌倉時代初期の公家。
sen.e: TAKASHINA no Yasutsune (1130 – December 20, 1201) was a court noble between the late Heian Period and the early Kamakura Period.
TAKASHINA no Yasutsune (1130 – December 20, 1201) was a court noble between the late Heian Period and the early Kamakura Period.
TAKASHINA no Yasutsune (1130 – December 20, 1201) was a court noble between the late Heian period and the early Kamakura period.
sen.cmt: period を小文字にしました。

sen.j: 後白河天皇の側近（院近臣）。
sen.e: Yasutsune was a close aide (In no Kinshin (the retired Emperor's courtier) to Emperor Goshirakawa.
Yasutsune was a close aide (In no Kinshin (the retired Emperor's courtier) to Emperor Goshirakawa.
Yasutsune was a close aide (In no Kinshin (the retired Emperor's courtier) to Emperor Goshirakawa.

sen.j: 大治5年（1130年）、父：若狭国守高階泰重と母：藤原宗兼の娘の子として生まれる。
sen.e: He was born the child of Wakasa no kami (Governor of Wakasa Province) TAKASHINA no Yasushige and the daughter of FUJIWARA no Munekane in 1130.
He was born the child of Wakasa no kami (Governor of Wakasa Province) TAKASHINA no Yasushige and the daughter of FUJIWARA no Munekane in 1130.
He was born the child of Wakasa no kami (Governor of Wakasa Province) TAKASHINA no Yasushige and the daughter of FUJIWARA no Munekane in 1130.

sen.j: 仁平元年（1151年）に近衛天皇の蔵人となる。
sen.e: In 1151, Yasutsuna was appointed as Kurodo to Emperor Konoe.
In 1151, Yasutsuna was appointed as Kurodo to Emperor Konoe.
In 1151, Yasutsuna was appointed as Kurodo (Chamberlain) to Emperor Konoe.
sen.cmt: 蔵人 の補足を追加しました。

sen.j: 久寿2年（1155年）左衛門少尉・検非違使となり、またこの年即位した新帝・後白河天皇の蔵人に任ぜられる。
sen.e: In 1155, Yasutsune was appointed as Saemon-no-shoi (one of the government posts) as well as kebiishi (the police and judicial chief) and, in addition, was appointed as Kurodo (Secretary) to the new Emperor Goshirakawa who ascended the throne that year.

In 1155, Yasutsune was appointed as Saemon-no-shoi (one of the government posts) as well as kebiishi (the police and judicial chief) and, in addition, was appointed as Kurodo (Secretary) to the new Emperor Goshirakawa who ascended the throne that year.

In 1155, Yasutsune was appointed as Saemon-no-shoi (one of the government posts) as well as kebiishi (the police and judicial chief) and, in addition, was appointed as Kurodo to the new Emperor Goshirakawa who ascended the throne that year.
sen.cmt: 蔵人 既出のため、補足を削除しました。

sen.j: 以後、後白河の側近となり、河内国守・出羽国守・摂津国守・少納言・右京大夫を歴任。
sen.e: Thereafter, Yasutsune became a close aide to Emperor Goshirakawa, successively holding the various posts including Kawachi no kuni no kami (Governor of Kawachi Province) Dewa no kuni no kami (Governor of Dewa Province), Settsu no kuni no kami (Governor of Settsu Province), Shonagon (Lesser Councilor) and Ukyo no daibu (Master of the Western Capital Offices).

Thereafter, Yasutsune became a close aide to Emperor Goshirakawa, successively holding the various posts including Kawachi no kuni no kami (Governor of Kawachi Province) Dewa no kuni no kami (Governor of Dewa Province), Settsu no kuni no kami (Governor of Settsu Province), Shonagon (Lesser Councilor) and Ukyo no daibu (Master of the Western Capital Offices).

Thereafter, Yasutsune became a close aide to Emperor Goshirakawa, successively holding the various posts including Kawachi no kuni no kami (Governor of Kawachi Province) Dewa no kuni no kami (Governor of Dewa Province), Settsu no kuni no kami (Governor of Settsu Province), Shonagon (lesser councilor of state) and Ukyo no daibu (Master of the Western Capital Offices).
sen.cmt: 少納言→Shonagon (lesser councilor of state) としました。

sen.j: 後白河上皇が院政を始めた際も院近臣として活躍。
sen.e: He played an active role as In no Kinshin when the retired Emperor Goshirakawa implemented the Cloistered government.
He played an active role as In no Kinshin when the retired Emperor Goshirakawa implemented the Cloistered government.
He played an active role as In no Kinshin when the Retired Emperor Goshirakawa implemented the cloistered government.

sen.j: 主に武家との折衝にあたるが、政権の中枢にあったために失脚することも多く、治承3年（1179年）平清盛による後白河院の鳥羽殿幽閉の際に解官されたのを手始めとして、復帰後の寿永2年（1183年）源義仲による再度の後白河院幽閉の際にも再び解官。
sen.e: One of the main functions of Yasutsune was to negotiate with samurai but, being at the center of the administration, he had numerous downfalls with the first one occurring in 1179 when the retired Emperor Goshirakawa was confined by TAIRA no Kiyomori whereby Yasutsune was removed from office and, in 1183, he was removed from office when the retired Emperor Goshirakawa was once again confined this time by MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka.

One of the main functions of Yasutsune was to negotiate with samurai but, being at the center of the administration, he had numerous downfalls with the first one occurring in 1179 when the retired Emperor Goshirakawa was confined by TAIRA no Kiyomori whereby Yasutsune was removed from office and, in 1183, he was removed from office when the retired Emperor Goshirakawa was once again confined this time by MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka.

One of the main functions of Yasutsune was to negotiate with samurai but, being at the center of the administration, he had numerous downfalls with the first one occurring in 1179 when the Retired Emperor Goshirakawa was confined by TAIRA no Kiyomori whereby Yasutsune was removed from office and, in 1183, he was removed from office when the Retired Emperor Goshirakawa was once again confined this time by MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka.

sen.j: このたびもまもなく復帰するが、今度は文治元年（1185年）源義経・源行家の謀叛への係累を疑われて、三度目の解官、さらには伊豆国への流罪となった。
sen.e: While Yasutsune soon returned to his previous post that time, he was subsequently removed from office for the third time and was also banished to Izu Province under suspicion of involving in the rebellion by MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune and MINAMOTO no Yukiie in 1185.

While Yasutsune soon returned to his previous post that time, he was subsequently removed from office for the third time and was also banished to Izu Province under suspicion of involving in the rebellion by MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune and MINAMOTO no Yukiie in 1185.

While Yasutsune soon returned to his previous post that time, he was subsequently removed from office for the third time and was also banished to Izu Province under suspicion of involving in the rebellion by MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune and MINAMOTO no Yukiie in 1185.

sen.j: 文治5年（1189年）に再出仕が赦され、建久2年（1191年）には正三位に昇る。
sen.e: In 1189, Yasutsune was again pardoned and was allowed to attend the court whereby rising to the court rank of Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank) in 1191.
In 1189, Yasutsune was again pardoned and was allowed to attend the court whereby rising to the court rank of Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank) in 1191.
In 1189, Yasutsune was again pardoned and was allowed to attend the court whereby rising to the court rank of Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank) in 1191.

sen.j: 同8年（1197年）に出家し、4年後の建仁元年（1201年）に没。
sen.e: In 1197, Yasutsune entered priesthood and died 4 years later in 1201.
In 1197, Yasutsune entered the priesthood and died 4 years later in 1201.
In 1197, Yasutsune entered the priesthood and died four years later in 1201.
sen.cmt: 数字をスペルアウトしました。

sen.j: 子に高階経仲がいる。
sen.e: TAKASHINA no Yasunaka was his child.
TAKASHINA no Yasunaka was his child.
TAKASHINA no Tsunenaka was his child.

sen.j: 日本一の大天狗？
sen.e: The greatest Tengu (long-nosed goblin) in Japan?
The greatest Tengu (long-nosed goblin) in Japan?
Argument regarding the greatest Tengu (long-nosed goblin) in Japan
sen.cmt: ？を使わない表現にしました。

sen.j: 源頼朝が泰経に宛てた書状の中で「日本第一の大天狗は余人の事に非ず候か」との表現があり、従来これは頼朝が後白河院を批判した語句であるとして、後白河院を形容する際に用いられることが多かった。
sen.e: In a letter written by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo addressed to Yasutsune, there was a phrase saying, "The greatest Tengu in Japan cannot be anyone else," which became established as an expression used by Yoritomo's to criticize the retired Emperor Goshirakawa and, consequently, was often quoted to describe that retired emperor.

In a letter written by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo addressed to Yasutsune, there was a phrase saying, "The greatest Tengu in Japan cannot be anyone else," which became established as an expression used by Yoritomo's to criticize the retired Emperor Goshirakawa and, consequently, was often quoted to describe that retired emperor.

In a letter written by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo addressed to Yasutsune, there was a phrase saying, 'The greatest Tengu in Japan cannot be anyone else,' which became established as an expression used by Yoritomo's to criticize the Retired Emperor Goshirakawa and, consequently, was often quoted to describe that retired emperor.

sen.j: しかし近年、この「日本一の大天狗」との表現は後白河院ではなく、泰経を指した文句ではないかとする説が浮上し（五味文彦など）、さらにまたそれに対して、やはり後白河院を指したものであろうとする再反論も出ている。
sen.e: Recently, however, a theory suggesting that the expression, "the greatest Tengu in Japan" was a phrase describing Yasutsune and not the retired Emperor Goshirakawa emerged (as offered by various people including Fumihiko GOMI) which was contradicted by an argument going back to the initial theory that the said phrase was after all describing the retired Emperor Goshirakawa.

Recently, however, a theory suggesting that the expression, "the greatest Tengu in Japan" was a phrase describing Yasutsune and not the retired Emperor Goshirakawa emerged (as offered by various people including Fumihiko GOMI) which was contradicted by an argument going back to the initial theory that the said phrase was after all describing the retired Emperor Goshirakawa.

Recently, however, a theory suggesting that the expression, 'the greatest Tengu in Japan' was a phrase describing Yasutsune and not the Retired Emperor Goshirakawa emerged (as offered by various people including Fumihiko GOMI) which was contradicted by an argument going back to the initial theory that the said phrase was after all describing the Retired Emperor Goshirakawa.
sen.cmt: " → ' としました。Retired としました。

March 1150: Appointed as Hikurodo (trainee in the Kurodo-dokoro or the Imperial Secretariat).
